Text

[Northanger Abbey]1-northanger abbey

by [Jane Austen]76-jane austen

CHAPTER 1

[No one who had ever seen [Catherine Morland]77-catherine in [her]77-catherine infancy]186-no one who had ever seen catherine morland in her infancy would have supposed [her]77-catherine born to be [an heroine]187-an heroine . [Her]77-catherine situation in life , the character of [[her]77-catherine father]188-her father and [mother]189-mother , [her]77-catherine own person and disposition , were all equally against [her]77-catherine . [[Her]77-catherine father]188-her father was [a clergyman]191-a clergyman , without being neglected , or poor , and [a very respectable man]192-a very respectable man , though [his]188-her father name was [Richard]78-captain tilney and [he]188-her father had never been handsome . [He]188-her father had a considerable independence besides two good livings and [he]188-her father was not in the least addicted to locking up [[his]188-her father daughters]193-his daughters . [[Her]77-catherine mother]194-her mother was [a woman of useful plain sense , with a good temper , and , what is more remarkable , with a good constitution]195-a woman of useful plain sense , with a good temper , and , what is more remarkable , with a good constitution . [She]194-her mother had [three sons]196-three sons before [Catherine]77-catherine was born ; and instead of dying in bringing the latter into [the world]197-the world , as [anybody]198-anybody might expect , [she]194-her mother still lived on lived to have [six children]199-six children more to see [them]199-six children growing up around [her]194-her mother , and to enjoy excellent health [herself]194-her mother . [A family of ten children]200-a family of ten children will be always called [a fine family]201-a fine family , where there are heads and arms and legs enough for the number ; but [the Morlands]79-the morlands had little other right to the word , for [they]79-the morlands were in general very plain , and [Catherine]77-catherine , for many years of [her]77-catherine life , as plain as any . [She]77-catherine had a thin awkward figure , a sallow skin without colour , dark lank hair , and strong features so much for [her]77-catherine person ; and not less unpropitious for heroism seemed [her]77-catherine mind . [She]77-catherine was fond of all boy s plays , and greatly preferred cricket not merely to dolls , but to the more heroic enjoyments of infancy , nursing a dormouse , feeding a canary - bird , or watering a rose - bush . Indeed [she]77-catherine had no taste for [a garden]202-a garden ; and if [she]77-catherine gathered flowers at all , it was chiefly for the pleasure of mischief at least so it was conjectured from [her]77-catherine always preferring those which [she]77-catherine was forbidden to take . Such were [her]77-catherine propensities [her]77-catherine abilities were quite as extraordinary . [She]77-catherine never could learn or understand anything before [she]77-catherine was taught ; and sometimes not even then , for [she]77-catherine was often inattentive , and occasionally stupid . [[Her]77-catherine mother]194-her mother was three months in teaching [her]77-catherine only to repeat the " Beggar s Petition "[77-catherine] ; and after all , [[her]77-catherine next sister]204-her next sister , [Sally]80-sarah , could say it better than [she]77-catherine did . Not that [Catherine]77-catherine was always stupid by no means ; [she]77-catherine learnt the fable of " [The Hare]81-the hare and [Many Friends]2118-many friends "[77-catherine] as quickly as [any girl in [England]2-england]205-any girl in england . [[Her]77-catherine mother]194-her mother wished [her]77-catherine to learn music ; and [Catherine]77-catherine was sure [she]77-catherine should like it , for [she]77-catherine was very fond of tinkling the keys of the old forlorn spinnet ; so , at eight years old [she]77-catherine began . [She]77-catherine learnt a year , and could not bear it ; and [Mrs. Morland]82-mrs. morland , who did not insist on [[her]82-mrs. morland daughters]207-her daughters being accomplished in spite of incapacity or distaste , allowed [her]77-catherine to leave off . The day which dismissed [the music - master]208-the music - master was one of the happiest of [Catherine]77-catherine s life . [Her]77-catherine taste for drawing was not superior ; though whenever [she]77-catherine could obtain the outside of a letter from [[her]77-catherine mother]194-her mother or seize upon any other odd piece of paper , [she]77-catherine did what [she]77-catherine could in that way , by drawing [houses]210-houses and trees , hens and chickens , all very much like one another . Writing and accounts [she]77-catherine was taught by [[her]77-catherine father]188-her father ; French by [[her]77-catherine mother]194-her mother : [her]77-catherine proficiency in either was not remarkable , and [she]77-catherine shirked [her]77-catherine lessons in both whenever [she]77-catherine could . What a strange , unaccountable character ! for with all these symptoms of profligacy at ten years old , [she]77-catherine had neither a bad heart nor a bad temper , was seldom stubborn , scarcely ever quarrelsome , and very kind to [the little ones]213-the little ones , with few interruptions of tyranny ; [she]77-catherine was moreover noisy and wild , hated confinement and cleanliness , and loved nothing so well in [the world]197-the world as rolling down [the green slope]215-the green slope at the back of [the house]216-the house .

Such was [Catherine Morland]77-catherine at ten . At fifteen , appearances were mending ; [she]77-catherine began to curl [her]77-catherine hair and long for balls ; [her]77-catherine complexion improved , [her]77-catherine features were softened by plumpness and colour , [her]77-catherine eyes gained more animation , and [her]77-catherine figure more consequence . [Her]77-catherine love of dirt gave way to an inclination for finery , and [she]77-catherine grew clean as [she]77-catherine grew smart ; [she]77-catherine had now the pleasure of sometimes hearing [[her]77-catherine father]188-her father and [mother]189-mother remark on [her]77-catherine personal improvement . " [Catherine]77-catherine grows quite a good - looking girl [she]77-catherine is almost pretty today , "[77-catherine] were words which caught [her]77-catherine ears now and then ; and how welcome were the sounds ! To look _ almost _ pretty is an acquisition of higher delight to [a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of [her]219-a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of her life than a beauty from her cradle life than a beauty from [her]219-a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of her life than a beauty from her cradle cradle]219-a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of her life than a beauty from her cradle can ever receive .

[Mrs. Morland]82-mrs. morland was [a very good woman]220-a very good woman , and wished to see [[her]82-mrs. morland children]221-her children everything [they]221-her children ought to be ; but [her]82-mrs. morland time was so much occupied in lying - in and teaching [the little ones]213-the little ones , that [[her]82-mrs. morland elder daughters]223-her elder daughters were inevitably left to shift for [themselves]223-her elder daughters ; and it was not very wonderful that [Catherine]77-catherine , who had by nature nothing heroic about [her]77-catherine , should prefer cricket , baseball , riding on horseback , and running about [the country]224-the country at the age of fourteen , to books or at least books of information for , provided that nothing like useful knowledge could be gained from [them]225-them , provided they were all story and no reflection , [she]77-catherine had never any objection to books at all . But from fifteen to seventeen [she]77-catherine was in training for [a heroine]226-a heroine ; [she]77-catherine read all such works as [heroines]227-heroines must read to supply [their]227-heroines memories with those quotations which are so serviceable and so soothing in the vicissitudes of [their]227-heroines eventful lives .

From [Pope]83-pope , [she]77-catherine learnt to censure [those who

" bear about the mockery of woe]2119-those who " bear about the mockery of woe . "[83-pope]

From [Gray]84-gray , that

" Many a flower is born to blush unseen , And waste its fragrance on the desert air . "[83-pope]

From [Thompson]85-thompson , that

" It is a delightful task To teach [the young idea]2120-the young idea how to shoot . "[83-pope]

And from [Shakespeare]86-shakespeare [she]77-catherine gained a great store of information amongst the rest , that

" Trifles light as air , Are , to the jealous , confirmation strong , As proofs of [Holy Writ]87-holy writ . "[83-pope]

That

" The poor beetle , which [we]2121-we tread upon , In corporal sufferance feels a pang as great As when [a giant dies]2122-a giant dies . "[83-pope]

And that [a young woman in love]228-a young woman in love always looks

" like Patience on a monument Smiling at [Grief]88-grief . "[228-a young woman in love]

So far [her]77-catherine improvement was sufficient and in many other points [she]77-catherine came on exceedingly well ; for though [she]77-catherine could not write sonnets , [she]77-catherine brought [herself]77-catherine to read them ; and though there seemed no chance of [her]77-catherine throwing a whole party into raptures by a prelude on the pianoforte , of [her]77-catherine own composition , [she]77-catherine could listen to [other people]229-other people s performance with very little fatigue . [Her]77-catherine greatest deficiency was in the pencil [she]77-catherine had no notion of drawing not enough even to attempt a sketch of [her]77-catherine lover s profile , that [she]77-catherine might be detected in the design . There [she]77-catherine fell miserably short of the true heroic height . At present [she]77-catherine did not know [her]77-catherine own poverty , for [she]77-catherine had [no lover to portray]230-no lover to portray . [She]77-catherine had reached the age of seventeen , without having seen [one amiable youth]231-one amiable youth who could call forth [her]77-catherine sensibility , without having inspired one real passion , and without having excited even any admiration but what was very moderate and very transient . This was strange indeed ! But strange things may be generally accounted for if their cause be fairly searched out . There was not [one lord in [the neighbourhood]233-the neighbourhood]232-one lord in the neighbourhood ; no not even [a baronet]234-a baronet . There was [not one family among [[their]236-their acquaintance who had reared and supported [a boy]238-a boy accidentally found at [their]236-their door]237-their acquaintance who had reared and supported a boy accidentally found at their door not [one young man whose origin was unknown]239-one young man whose origin was unknown . [[Her]77-catherine father]188-her father had [no ward]241-no ward]235-not one family among their acquaintance who had reared and supported a boy accidentally found at their door not one young man whose origin was unknown . her father had no ward , and [the squire of [the parish]243-the parish]242-the squire of the parish no [children]244-children .

But when [a young lady]245-a young lady is to be [a heroine]226-a heroine , the perverseness of [forty surrounding families]247-forty surrounding families can not prevent [her]245-a young lady . Something must and will happen to throw [a hero]248-a hero in [her]245-a young lady way .

[Mr. Allen]89-mr. allen , who owned [the chief of [the property about [Fullerton]3-fullerton]250-the property about fullerton , [the village in [Wiltshire]4-wiltshire where [the Morlands]79-the morlands lived]251-the village in wiltshire where the morlands lived]249-the chief of the property about fullerton , the village in wiltshire where the morlands lived , was ordered to [Bath]5-bath for the benefit of [a gouty constitution]252-a gouty constitution and [[his]89-mr. allen lady]253-his lady , [a good - humoured woman]254-a good - humoured woman , fond of [Miss Morland]90-miss morland , and probably aware that if adventures will not befall [a young lady]245-a young lady in [[her]245-a young lady [own village]257-own village]256-her own village , [she]245-a young lady must seek [them]258-them abroad , invited [her]245-a young lady to go with [them]258-them . [Mr.]259-mr. and [Mrs. Morland]82-mrs. morland were all compliance , and [Catherine]77-catherine all happiness .

CHAPTER 2

In addition to what has been already said of [Catherine Morland]77-catherine s personal and mental endowments , when about to be launched into all the difficulties and dangers of a six weeks residence in [Bath]5-bath , it may be stated , for [the reader]260-the reader s more certain information , lest the following pages should otherwise fail of giving any idea of what [her]77-catherine character is meant to be , that [her]77-catherine heart was affectionate ; [her]77-catherine disposition cheerful and open , without conceit or affectation of any kind [her]77-catherine manners just removed from the awkwardness and shyness of [a girl]261-a girl ; [her]77-catherine person pleasing , and , when in good looks , pretty and [her]77-catherine mind about as ignorant and uninformed as [the female mind at seventeen]262-the female mind at seventeen usually is .

When the hour of departure drew near , the maternal anxiety of [Mrs. Morland]82-mrs. morland will be naturally supposed to be most severe . A thousand alarming presentiments of evil to [[her]82-mrs. morland beloved]263-her beloved [Catherine]77-catherine from this terrific separation must oppress [her]82-mrs. morland heart with sadness , and drown [her]82-mrs. morland in tears for the last day or two of [their]264-their being together ; and advice of the most important and applicable nature must of course flow from [her]82-mrs. morland wise lips in [their]264-their parting conference in [[her]82-mrs. morland closet]265-her closet . Cautions against the violence of [such noblemen]266-such noblemen and [baronets]267-baronets as delight in forcing [young ladies]268-young ladies away to [some remote farm - house]269-some remote farm - house , must , at such a moment , relieve the fulness of [her]82-mrs. morland heart . Who would not think so ? But [Mrs. Morland]82-mrs. morland knew so little of [lords]270-lords and [baronets]267-baronets , that [she]82-mrs. morland entertained no notion of [their]264-their general mischievousness , and was wholly unsuspicious of danger to [[her]82-mrs. morland daughter]272-her daughter from [their]264-their machinations . [Her]82-mrs. morland cautions were confined to the following points . " [I]82-mrs. morland beg , [Catherine]77-catherine , [you]77-catherine will always wrap [yourself]77-catherine up very warm about the throat , when [you]77-catherine come from [the rooms]2123-the rooms at night ; and [I]82-mrs. morland wish [you]77-catherine would try to keep some account of the money [you]77-catherine spend ; [I]82-mrs. morland will give [you]77-catherine this little book on purpose . "[82-mrs. morland]

[Sally]80-sarah , or rather [Sarah]80-sarah ( for what [young lady of common gentility]273-young lady of common gentility will reach the age of sixteen without altering [her]273-young lady of common gentility name as far as [she]273-young lady of common gentility can ? ) , must from situation be at this time [the intimate friend and confidante of [[her]80-sarah sister]275-her sister]274-the intimate friend and confidante of her sister . It is remarkable , however , that [she]82-mrs. morland neither insisted on [Catherine]77-catherine s writing by every post , nor exacted [her]82-mrs. morland promise of transmitting the character of [every new acquaintance]276-every new acquaintance , nor a detail of every interesting conversation that [Bath]5-bath might produce . Everything indeed relative to this important journey was done , on the part of [the Morlands]79-the morlands , with a degree of moderation and composure , which seemed rather consistent with the common feelings of common life , than with the refined susceptibilities , the tender emotions which the first separation of [a heroine]226-a heroine from [[her]80-sarah family]278-her family ought always to excite . [[Her]77-catherine father]188-her father , instead of giving [her]77-catherine an unlimited order on [[his]188-her father banker]280-his banker , or even putting an hundred pounds bank - bill into [her]77-catherine hands , gave [her]77-catherine only ten guineas , and promised [her]77-catherine more when [she]77-catherine wanted it .

Under these unpromising auspices , the parting took place , and the journey began . It was performed with suitable quietness and uneventful safety . [Neither robbers]281-neither robbers nor [tempests]282-tempests befriended [them]283-them , nor [one lucky overturn]284-one lucky overturn to introduce [them]283-them to [the hero]285-the hero . Nothing more alarming occurred than a fear , on [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen s side , of having once left [her]91-mrs. allen clogs behind [her]91-mrs. allen at [an inn]286-an inn , and that fortunately proved to be groundless .

[They]287-they arrived at [Bath]5-bath . [Catherine]77-catherine was all eager delight [her]77-catherine eyes were here , there , everywhere , as [they]287-they approached [[its]5-bath fine and striking environs]288-its fine and striking environs , and afterwards drove through [those streets]289-those streets which conducted [them]287-they to [the hotel]290-the hotel . [She]77-catherine was come to be happy , and [she]77-catherine felt happy already .

[They]287-they were soon settled in [comfortable lodgings in [Pulteney Street]7-pulteney street]291-comfortable lodgings in pulteney street .

It is now expedient to give some description of [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen , that [the reader]260-the reader may be able to judge in what manner [her]91-mrs. allen actions will hereafter tend to promote the general distress of the work , and how [she]91-mrs. allen will , probably , contribute to reduce poor [Catherine]77-catherine to all the desperate wretchedness of which a last volume is capable whether by [her]91-mrs. allen imprudence , vulgarity , or jealousy whether by intercepting [her]91-mrs. allen letters , ruining [her]91-mrs. allen character , or turning [her]91-mrs. allen out of doors .

[Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen was [one of that numerous class of females , whose society can raise no other emotion than surprise at there being [any men in [the world]197-the world who could like [them]296-them well enough to marry [them]296-them]294-any men in the world who could like them well enough to marry them]293-one of that numerous class of females , whose society can raise no other emotion than surprise at there being any men in the world who could like them well enough to marry them . [She]91-mrs. allen had neither beauty , genius , accomplishment , nor manner . The air of [a gentlewoman , a great deal of quiet , inactive good temper , and a trifling turn of mind]297-a gentlewoman , a great deal of quiet , inactive good temper , and a trifling turn of mind were all that could account for [her]91-mrs. allen being the choice of [a sensible , intelligent man like [Mr. Allen]89-mr. allen]298-a sensible , intelligent man like mr. allen . In one respect [she]91-mrs. allen was admirably fitted to introduce [a young lady]245-a young lady into public , being as fond of going everywhere and seeing everything [herself]91-mrs. allen as [any young lady]300-any young lady could be . Dress was [her]91-mrs. allen passion . [She]91-mrs. allen had a most harmless delight in being fine ; and [our]301-our heroine s entree into life could not take place till after three or four days had been spent in learning what was mostly worn , and [[her]91-mrs. allen chaperone]302-her chaperone was provided with a dress of the newest fashion . [Catherine]77-catherine too made some purchases [herself]77-catherine , and when all these matters were arranged , the important evening came which was to usher [her]77-catherine into [the Upper Rooms]303-the upper rooms . [Her]77-catherine hair was cut and dressed by the best hand , [her]77-catherine clothes put on with care , and both [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen and [[her]91-mrs. allen maid]304-her maid declared [she]77-catherine looked quite as [she]77-catherine should do . With such encouragement , [Catherine]77-catherine hoped at least to pass uncensured through [the crowd]305-the crowd . As for admiration , it was always very welcome when it came , but [she]77-catherine did not depend on it .

[Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen was so long in dressing that [they]306-they did not enter [the ballroom]307-the ballroom till late . The season was full , [the room]308-the room crowded , and [the two ladies]309-the two ladies squeezed in as well as [they]309-the two ladies could . As for [Mr. Allen]89-mr. allen , [he]89-mr. allen repaired directly to [the card - room]310-the card - room , and left [them]306-they to enjoy a mob by [themselves]306-they . With more care for the safety of [her]91-mrs. allen new gown than for the comfort of [[her]91-mrs. allen protegee]311-her protegee , [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen made [her]91-mrs. allen way through [the throng of men by the door]312-the throng of men by the door , as swiftly as the necessary caution would allow ; [Catherine]77-catherine , however , kept close at [her]77-catherine side , and linked [her]77-catherine arm too firmly within [[her]77-catherine friend]313-her friend s to be torn asunder by any common effort of [a struggling assembly]314-a struggling assembly . But to [her]77-catherine utter amazement [she]77-catherine found that to proceed along [the room]308-the room was by no means the way to disengage [themselves]306-they from [the crowd]305-the crowd ; it seemed rather to increase as [they]306-they went on , whereas [she]77-catherine had imagined that when once fairly within the door , [they]306-they should easily find seats and be able to watch the dances with perfect convenience . But this was far from being the case , and though by unwearied diligence [they]306-they gained even the top of [the room]308-the room , [their]306-they situation was just the same ; [they]306-they saw nothing of [the dancers]318-the dancers but the high feathers of [some of [the ladies]320-the ladies]319-some of the ladies . Still [they]306-they moved on something better was yet in view ; and by a continued exertion of strength and ingenuity [they]306-they found [themselves]306-they at last in the passage behind the highest bench . Here there was something less of [crowd]321-crowd than below ; and hence [Miss Morland]90-miss morland had a comprehensive view of all the company beneath [her]90-miss morland , and of all the dangers of [her]90-miss morland late passage through [them]306-they . It was a splendid sight , and [she]90-miss morland began , for the first time that evening , to feel [herself]90-miss morland at a ball : [she]90-miss morland longed to dance , but [she]90-miss morland had [not an acquaintance in [the room]308-the room]322-not an acquaintance in the room . [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen did all that [she]91-mrs. allen could do in such a case by saying very placidly , every now and then , " [I]91-mrs. allen wish [you]77-catherine could dance , [[my]91-mrs. allen dear]2124-my dear [I]91-mrs. allen wish [you]77-catherine could get [a partner]2125-a partner . "[91-mrs. allen] For some time [[her]91-mrs. allen young friend]324-her young friend felt obliged to [her]91-mrs. allen for these wishes ; but they were repeated so often , and proved so totally ineffectual , that [Catherine]77-catherine grew tired at last , and would thank [her]91-mrs. allen no more .

[They]325-we were not long able , however , to enjoy the repose of the eminence [they]325-we had so laboriously gained . [Everybody]326-everybody was shortly in motion for tea , and [they]326-everybody must squeeze out like [the rest]327-the rest . [Catherine]77-catherine began to feel something of disappointment [she]77-catherine was tired of being continually pressed against by [people]328-people , the generality of whose faces possessed nothing to interest , and with all of whom [she]77-catherine was so wholly unacquainted that [she]77-catherine could not relieve the irksomeness of imprisonment by the exchange of a syllable with [any of [[her]77-catherine fellow captives]330-her fellow captives]329-any of her fellow captives ; and when at last arrived in [the tea - room]331-the tea - room , [she]77-catherine felt yet more the awkwardness of having [no party to join]332-no party to join , [no acquaintance to claim]333-no acquaintance to claim , [no gentleman]334-no gentleman to assist [them]325-we . [They]325-we saw nothing of [Mr. Allen]89-mr. allen ; and after looking about [them]325-we in vain for a more eligible situation , were obliged to sit down at the end of a table , at which [a large party]335-a large party were already placed , without having anything to do [there]336-there , or [anybody]198-anybody to speak to , except [each other]338-each other .

[Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen congratulated [herself]91-mrs. allen , as soon as [they]325-we were seated , on having preserved [her]91-mrs. allen gown from injury . " It would have been very shocking to have it torn , "[91-mrs. allen] said [she]91-mrs. allen , " would not it ? It is such a delicate muslin . For [my]91-mrs. allen part [I]91-mrs. allen have not seen anything [I]91-mrs. allen like so well in [the whole room]2126-the whole room , [I]91-mrs. allen assure [you]91-mrs. allen . "[91-mrs. allen]

" How uncomfortable it is , "[77-catherine] whispered [Catherine]77-catherine , " not to have [a single acquaintance]2127-a single acquaintance [here]2128-here ! "[77-catherine]

" Yes , [[my]91-mrs. allen dear]2124-my dear , "[91-mrs. allen] replied [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen , with perfect serenity , " it is very uncomfortable indeed . "[91-mrs. allen]

" What shall [we]325-we do ? [The gentlemen]2130-the gentlemen and [ladies at this table]2131-ladies at this table look as if [they]2131-ladies at this table wondered why [we]325-we came here [we]325-we seem forcing [ourselves]325-we into [their]2131-ladies at this table party . "[91-mrs. allen]

" Aye , so [we]325-we do . That is very disagreeable . [I]91-mrs. allen wish [we]325-we had a large acquaintance here . "[91-mrs. allen]

" [I]91-mrs. allen wish [we]325-we had _ any ; _ it would be [somebody]2132-somebody to go to . "[91-mrs. allen]

" Very true , [[my]91-mrs. allen dear]2124-my dear ; and if [we]325-we knew [anybody]198-anybody [we]325-we would join [them]198-anybody directly . [The Skinners]2135-the skinners were here last year [I]91-mrs. allen wish [they]2135-the skinners were here now . "[91-mrs. allen]

" Had not [we]325-we better go away as it is ? Here are no tea - things for [us]325-we , [you]91-mrs. allen see . "[91-mrs. allen]

" No more there are , indeed . How very provoking ! But [I]91-mrs. allen think [we]325-we had better sit still , for one gets so tumbled in [such a crowd]2136-such a crowd ! " No , indeed , it looks very nice . After some time [they]339-they received an offer of tea from [one of [[their]339-they neighbours]341-their neighbours]340-one of their neighbours ; it was thankfully accepted , and this introduced a light conversation with [the gentleman who offered it]342-the gentleman who offered it , which was the only time that [anybody]198-anybody spoke to [them]339-they during the evening , till [they]339-they were discovered and joined by [Mr. Allen]89-mr. allen when the dance was over .

" Well , [Miss Morland]90-miss morland , "[89-mr. allen] said [he]89-mr. allen , directly , " [I]89-mr. allen hope [you]90-miss morland have had an agreeable ball . "[89-mr. allen]

" Very agreeable indeed , "[344-she] [she]344-she replied , vainly endeavouring to hide a great yawn .

" [I]345-his wife wish [she]2144-a strange - looking woman had been able to dance , "[345-his wife] said [[his]89-mr. allen wife]345-his wife ; " [I]345-his wife wish [we]339-they could have got [a partner]2125-a partner for [her]2144-a strange - looking woman . " [We]346-the company shall do better another evening [I]89-mr. allen hope , "[89-mr. allen] was [Mr. Allen]89-mr. allen s consolation .

[The company]346-the company began to disperse when the dancing was over enough to leave space for [the remainder]347-the remainder to walk about in some comfort ; and now was the time for [a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening]348-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening , to be noticed and admired . [She]348-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening was now seen by [many young men who had not been near [her]348-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening before]350-many young men who had not been near her before . Yet [Catherine]77-catherine was in very good looks , and had [the company]346-the company only seen [her]77-catherine three years before , [they]346-the company would _ now _ have thought [her]77-catherine exceedingly handsome .

[She]77-catherine _ was _ looked at , however , and with some admiration ; for , in [her]77-catherine own hearing , [two gentlemen]355-two gentlemen pronounced [her]77-catherine to be [a pretty girl]356-a pretty girl . CHAPTER 3

Every morning now brought [its]360-its regular duties [shops]361-shops were to be visited ; [some new part of [the town]363-the town]362-some new part of the town to be looked at ; and [the pump - room]364-the pump - room to be attended , where [they]355-two gentlemen paraded up and down for an hour , looking at [everybody]326-everybody and speaking to [no one]366-no one . The wish of [a numerous acquaintance in [Bath]5-bath]367-a numerous acquaintance in bath was still uppermost with [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen , and [she]91-mrs. allen repeated it after every fresh proof , which every morning brought , of [her]91-mrs. allen knowing [nobody]2139-nobody at all .

[They]355-two gentlemen made [their]355-two gentlemen appearance in [the Lower Rooms]369-the lower rooms ; and here [fortune]370-fortune was more favourable to [[our]371-our heroine]372-our heroine . [The master of the ceremonies]373-the master of the ceremonies introduced to [her]91-mrs. allen [a very gentlemanlike young man as [a partner]2125-a partner]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner ; [his]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner name was [Tilney]95-miss tilney . [He]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner seemed to be about four or five and twenty , was rather tall , had a pleasing countenance , a very intelligent and lively eye , and , if not quite handsome , was very near it . [His]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner address was good , and [Catherine]77-catherine felt [herself]77-catherine in high luck . There was little leisure for speaking while [they]376-they danced ; but when [they]376-they were seated at tea , [she]77-catherine found [him]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner as agreeable as [she]77-catherine had already given [him]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner credit for being . [He]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner talked with fluency and spirit and there was an archness and pleasantry in [his]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner manner which interested , though it was hardly understood by [her]77-catherine . After chatting some time on such matters as naturally arose from the objects around [them]376-they , [he]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner suddenly addressed [her]77-catherine with " [I]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner have hitherto been very remiss , [madam]2147-madam , in the proper attentions of [a partner here]2148-a partner here ; [I]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner have not yet asked [you]77-catherine how long [you]77-catherine have been in [Bath]5-bath ; whether [you]77-catherine were ever [here]2128-here before ; whether [you]77-catherine have been at [the Upper Rooms]303-the upper rooms , [the theatre]2151-the theatre , and the concert ; and how [you]77-catherine like [the place]2152-the place altogether . [I]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner have been very negligent but are [you]77-catherine now at leisure to satisfy [me]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner in these particulars ? If [you]77-catherine are [I]374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner will begin directly . "[374-a very gentlemanlike young man as a partner]

" [You]77-catherine need not give [yourself]77-catherine that trouble , [sir]2153-sir . "[377-i]

" No trouble , [I]377-i assure [you]77-catherine , [madam]2147-madam . "[377-i] Then forming [his]377-i features into a set smile , and affectedly softening [his]377-i voice , [he]377-i added , with a simpering air , " Have [you]77-catherine been long in [Bath]2155-bath , [madam]2147-madam ? "[377-i]

" About a week , [sir]2153-sir , "[77-catherine] replied [Catherine]77-catherine , trying not to laugh .

" Really ! "[377-i] with affected astonishment .

" Why should [you]377-i be surprised , [sir]2153-sir ? "[377-i]

" Why , indeed ! "[377-i] said [he]377-i , in [his]377-i natural tone . " But some emotion must appear to be raised by [your]77-catherine reply , and surprise is more easily assumed , and not less reasonable than any other . Now let [us]2159-us go on . Were [you]377-i never here before , [madam]2147-madam ? "[377-i]

" Never , [sir]2153-sir . "[377-i]

" Indeed ! Have [you]377-i yet honoured [the Upper Rooms]303-the upper rooms ? "[377-i]

" Yes , [sir]2153-sir , [I]377-i was [there]336-there last Monday . "[377-i]

" Have [you]377-i been to [the theatre]2151-the theatre ? "[377-i]

" Yes , [sir]2153-sir , [I]377-i was at the play on Tuesday . "[377-i]

" To the concert ? "[377-i]

" Yes , [sir]2153-sir , on Wednesday . "[377-i]

" And are [you]377-i altogether pleased with Bath ? "[377-i]

" Yes [I]377-i like it very well . "[377-i]

" Now [I]377-i must give one smirk , and then [we]2168-we may be rational again . "[377-i] [Catherine]77-catherine turned away [her]77-catherine head , not knowing whether [she]77-catherine might venture to laugh . " [I]378-i see what [you]77-catherine think of [me]378-i , "[378-i] said [he]378-i gravely " [I]377-i shall make but a poor figure in [your]77-catherine journal tomorrow . "[377-i]

" [My]377-i journal ! "[377-i]

" Yes , [I]377-i know exactly what [you]77-catherine will say : Friday , went to [the Lower Rooms]369-the lower rooms ; wore [my]377-i sprigged muslin robe with blue trimmings plain black shoes appeared to much advantage ; but was strangely harassed by [a queer , half - witted man , who would make [me]377-i dance with [him]378-i , and distressed [me]377-i by [his]378-i nonsense]2170-a queer , half - witted man , who would make me dance with him , and distressed me by his nonsense . "[377-i]

" Indeed [I]377-i shall say no such thing . "[377-i]

" If [you]77-catherine please . "[377-i]

" [I]377-i danced with [a very agreeable young man]2171-a very agreeable young man , introduced by [Mr. King]96-mr. king ; had a great deal of conversation with [him]2171-a very agreeable young man seems [a most extraordinary genius]2172-a most extraordinary genius hope [I]377-i may know more of [him]2171-a very agreeable young man . _ That _ , [madam]2147-madam , is what [I]377-i _ wish _ [you]2147-madam to say . "[377-i]

" But , perhaps , [I]377-i keep no journal . "[377-i]

" Perhaps [you]2147-madam are not sitting in [this room]2174-this room , and [I]377-i am not sitting by [you]2147-madam . These are points in which a doubt is equally possible . Not keep a journal ! How are [[your]2147-madam absent cousins]2175-your absent cousins to understand the tenour of [your]2147-madam life in [Bath]5-bath without one ? How are the civilities and compliments of every day to be related as they ought to be , unless noted down every evening in a journal ? How are [your]2147-madam various dresses to be remembered , and the particular state of [your]2147-madam complexion , and curl of [your]2147-madam hair to be described in all [their]2176-their diversities , without having constant recourse to a journal ? [[My]377-i dear madam]2177-my dear madam , [I]377-i am not so ignorant of [young ladies]268-young ladies ways as [you]2147-madam wish to believe [me]377-i ; it is this delightful habit of journaling which largely contributes to form the easy style of writing for which [ladies]2179-ladies are so generally celebrated . [Everybody]326-everybody allows that the talent of writing agreeable letters is peculiarly female . [Nature]97-nature may have done something , but [I]377-i am sure it must be essentially assisted by the practice of keeping a journal . "[377-i]

" [I]77-catherine have sometimes thought , "[77-catherine] said [Catherine]77-catherine , doubtingly , " whether [ladies]2179-ladies do write so much better letters than [gentlemen]2182-gentlemen ! That is [I]77-catherine should not think the superiority was always on [our]2183-our side . "[77-catherine]

" As far as [I]377-i have had opportunity of judging , it appears to [me]377-i that the usual style of letter - writing among [women]2184-women is faultless , except in three particulars . "[377-i]

" And what are [they]2185-they ? "[77-catherine]

" A general deficiency of subject , a total inattention to stops , and a very frequent ignorance of grammar . "[377-i]

" Upon [my]77-catherine word ! [I]77-catherine need not have been afraid of disclaiming the compliment . [You]2147-madam do not think too highly of [us]2183-our in that way . "[77-catherine]

" [I]377-i should no more lay it down as a general rule that [women]2184-women write better letters than [men]2187-men , than that [they]2184-women sing better duets , or draw better landscapes . In every power , of which taste is the foundation , excellence is pretty fairly divided between the sexes . "[377-i]

[They]379-they were interrupted by [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen : " [[My]91-mrs. allen dear]2124-my dear [Catherine]77-catherine , "[91-mrs. allen] said [she]91-mrs. allen , " do take this pin out of [my]91-mrs. allen sleeve ; [I]91-mrs. allen am afraid it has torn a hole already ; [I]91-mrs. allen shall be quite sorry if it has , for this is a favourite gown , though it cost but nine shillings a yard . "[91-mrs. allen]

" That is exactly what [I]98-henry should have guessed it , [madam]2147-madam , "[98-henry] said [Mr. Tilney]98-henry , looking at the muslin .

" Do [you]98-henry understand muslins , [sir]2153-sir ? "[377-i]

" Particularly well ; [I]91-mrs. allen always buy [my]91-mrs. allen own cravats , and am allowed to be [an excellent judge]2191-an excellent judge ; and [[my]91-mrs. allen sister]2192-my sister has often trusted [me]91-mrs. allen in the choice of a gown . [I]91-mrs. allen bought one for [her]2192-my sister the other day , and it was pronounced to be a prodigious bargain by [every lady who saw it]2193-every lady who saw it . [I]91-mrs. allen gave but five shillings a yard for it , and a true Indian muslin . "[91-mrs. allen]

[Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen was quite struck by [his]98-henry genius . " [Men]2187-men commonly take so little notice of those things , "[91-mrs. allen] said [she]91-mrs. allen ; " [I]91-mrs. allen can never get [Mr. Allen]89-mr. allen to know one of [my]91-mrs. allen gowns from another . " [I]91-mrs. allen hope [I]91-mrs. allen am , [madam]2147-madam . "[91-mrs. allen]

" And pray , [sir]2153-sir , what do [you]2153-sir think of [Miss Morland]90-miss morland s gown ? "[91-mrs. allen]

" It is very pretty , [madam]2147-madam , "[98-henry] said [he]98-henry , gravely examining it ; " but [I]98-henry do not think it will wash well ; [I]98-henry am afraid it will fray . "[98-henry]

" How can [you]2153-sir , "[77-catherine] said [Catherine]77-catherine , laughing , " be so "[77-catherine] [She]77-catherine had almost said " strange . "[91-mrs. allen]

" [I]91-mrs. allen am quite of [your]2153-sir opinion , [sir]2153-sir , "[91-mrs. allen] replied [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen ; " and so [I]91-mrs. allen told [Miss Morland]90-miss morland when [she]90-miss morland bought it . "[91-mrs. allen]

" But then [you]2147-madam know , [madam]2147-madam , muslin always turns to some account or other ; [Miss Morland]90-miss morland will get enough out of it for a handkerchief , or a cap , or a cloak . Muslin can never be said to be wasted . [I]98-henry have heard [[my]98-henry sister]2192-my sister say so forty times , when [she]2192-my sister has been extravagant in buying more than [she]2192-my sister wanted , or careless in cutting it to pieces . "[98-henry]

" [Bath]2155-bath is [a charming place]2204-a charming place , [sir]2153-sir ; there are so many [good shops]2206-good shops [here]2128-here . [We]2208-we are sadly off in [the country]224-the country ; not but what [we]2208-we have very good shops in [Salisbury]8-salisbury , but it is so far to go eight miles is a long way ; [Mr. Allen]89-mr. allen says it is nine , measured nine ; but [I]380-i am sure it can not be more than eight ; and it is such a fag [I]380-i come back tired to death . Now , here [one]2210-one can step out of doors and get a thing in five minutes . "[380-i]

[Mr. Tilney]98-henry was polite enough to seem interested in what [she]380-i said ; and [she]380-i kept [him]98-henry on the subject of muslins till the dancing recommenced . [Catherine]77-catherine feared , as [she]77-catherine listened to [their]381-they discourse , that [he]98-henry indulged [himself]98-henry a little too much with the foibles of others . " What are [you]77-catherine thinking of so earnestly ? "[98-henry] said [he]98-henry , as [they]381-they walked back to [the ballroom]307-the ballroom ; " not of [[your]77-catherine partner]2211-your partner , [I]98-henry hope , for , by that shake of the head , [your]77-catherine meditations are not satisfactory . "[98-henry]

[Catherine]77-catherine coloured , and said , " [I]77-catherine was not thinking of anything . "[77-catherine]

" That is artful and deep , to be sure ; but [I]98-henry had rather be told at once that [you]98-henry will not tell [me]98-henry . "[98-henry]

" Well then , [I]77-catherine will not . "[77-catherine]

" Thank [you]98-henry ; for now [we]381-they shall soon be acquainted , as [I]98-henry am authorized to tease [you]98-henry on this subject whenever [we]381-they meet , and nothing in [the world]197-the world advances intimacy so much . "[98-henry]

[They]381-they danced again ; and , when the assembly closed , parted , on [the lady]383-the lady s side at least , with a strong inclination for continuing the acquaintance . Whether [she]383-the lady thought of [him]384-he so much , while [she]383-the lady drank [her]383-the lady warm wine and water , and prepared [herself]383-the lady for bed , as to dream of [him]384-he when there , can not be ascertained ; but [I]0-i hope it was no more than in a slight slumber , or a morning doze at most ; for if it be true , as [a celebrated writer]385-a celebrated writer has maintained , that [no young lady]386-no young lady can be justified in falling in love before [the gentleman]387-the gentleman s love is declared,[1 ] it must be very improper that [a young lady]245-a young lady should dream of [a gentleman]389-a gentleman before [the gentleman]387-the gentleman is first known to have dreamt of [her]245-a young lady . How proper [Mr. Tilney]98-henry might be as [a dreamer]391-a dreamer or [a lover]392-a lover had not yet perhaps entered [Mr. Allen]89-mr. allen s head , but that [he]384-he was not objectionable as a common acquaintance for [his]384-he young charge [he]384-he was on inquiry satisfied ; for [he]384-he had early in the evening taken pains to know who [[her]383-the lady partner]393-her partner was , and had been assured of [Mr. Tilney]98-henry s being [a clergyman]191-a clergyman , and of [a very respectable family in [Gloucestershire]9-gloucestershire]395-a very respectable family in gloucestershire .

[ 1 ] Vide a letter from [Mr. Richardson]99-mr. richardson , No . 97 , Vol . ii , [Rambler]100-rambler .

CHAPTER 4

With more than usual eagerness did [Catherine]77-catherine hasten to [the pump - room]364-the pump - room the next day , secure within [herself]77-catherine of seeing [Mr. Tilney]98-henry [there]336-there before the morning were over , and ready to meet [him]98-henry with a smile ; but no smile was demanded [Mr. Tilney]98-henry did not appear . Every creature in [Bath]5-bath , except [himself]98-henry , was to be seen in [the room]308-the room at different periods of the fashionable hours ; [crowds of people]399-crowds of people were every moment passing in and out , up the steps and down ; people whom [nobody cared about]400-nobody cared about , and [nobody wanted to see]401-nobody wanted to see ; and [he]98-henry only was absent . " What [a delightful place Bath]2213-a delightful place bath is , "[91-mrs. allen] said [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen as [they]402-we sat down near the great clock , after parading [the room]308-the room till [they]402-we were tired ; " and how pleasant it would be if [we]402-we had any acquaintance here . "[91-mrs. allen]

This sentiment had been uttered so often in vain that [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen had no particular reason to hope it would be followed with more advantage now ; but [we]402-we are told to " despair of nothing [we]402-we would attain , "[402-we] as " unwearied diligence [our]402-we point would gain "[402-we] ; and the unwearied diligence with which [she]91-mrs. allen had every day wished for the same thing was at length to have its just reward , for hardly had [she]91-mrs. allen been seated ten minutes before [a lady of about [her]404-a lady of about her own age , who was sitting by her , and had been looking at her attentively for several minutes own age , who was sitting by [her]91-mrs. allen , and had been looking at [her]91-mrs. allen attentively for several minutes]404-a lady of about her own age , who was sitting by her , and had been looking at her attentively for several minutes , addressed [her]91-mrs. allen with great complaisance in these words : " [I]405-the stranger think , [madam]2147-madam , [I]405-the stranger can not be mistaken ; it is a long time since [I]405-the stranger had the pleasure of seeing [you]91-mrs. allen , but is not [your]91-mrs. allen name [Allen]91-mrs. allen ? "[405-the stranger] This question answered , as it readily was , [the stranger]405-the stranger pronounced [hers]91-mrs. allen to be [Thorpe]101-miss thorpe ; and [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen immediately recognized the features of [a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom [she]91-mrs. allen had seen only once since [their]407-their respective marriages , and that many years ago]406-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages , and that many years ago . [Their]407-their joy on this meeting was very great , as well it might , since [they]407-their had been contented to know nothing of [each other]338-each other for the last fifteen years . Compliments on good looks now passed ; and , after observing how time had slipped away since [they]407-their were last together , how little [they]407-their had thought of meeting in [Bath]5-bath , and what a pleasure it was to see [an old friend]409-an old friend , [they]407-their proceeded to make inquiries and give intelligence as to [[their]407-their families]410-their families , [sisters]411-sisters , and [cousins]412-cousins , talking both together , far more ready to give than to receive information , and each hearing very little of what [the other]413-the other said . [Mrs. Thorpe]102-mrs. thorpe , however , had one great advantage as [a talker]414-a talker , over [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen , in [a family of [children]244-children]415-a family of children ; and when [she]102-mrs. thorpe expatiated on the talents of [[her]102-mrs. thorpe sons]417-her sons , and the beauty of [[her]102-mrs. thorpe daughters]207-her daughters , when [she]102-mrs. thorpe related [their]407-their different situations and views that [John]103-john was at [Oxford]10-oxford , [Edward]104-edward at [Merchant Taylors]11-merchant taylors , and [William]105-william at [sea]419-sea and all of [them]407-their more beloved and respected in [their]407-their different station than [any other three beings]420-any other three beings ever were , [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen had no similar information to give , no similar triumphs to press on the unwilling and unbelieving ear of [[her]91-mrs. allen friend]313-her friend , and was forced to sit and appear to listen to all these maternal effusions , consoling [herself]91-mrs. allen , however , with the discovery , which [her]91-mrs. allen keen eye soon made , that the lace on [Mrs. Thorpe]102-mrs. thorpe s pelisse was not half so handsome as that on [her]91-mrs. allen own .

" Here come [[my]102-mrs. thorpe dear girls]2215-my dear girls , "[102-mrs. thorpe] cried [Mrs. Thorpe]102-mrs. thorpe , pointing at [three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards [her]102-mrs. thorpe]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her . " [[My]102-mrs. thorpe dear]2124-my dear [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen , [I]102-mrs. thorpe long to introduce [them]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her ; [they]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her will be so delighted to see [you]2124-my dear : [the tallest]2217-the tallest is [Isabella]106-isabella , [[my]102-mrs. thorpe eldest]2218-my eldest ; is not [she]106-isabella [a fine young woman]2219-a fine young woman ? [The others]2220-the others are very much admired too , but [I]102-mrs. thorpe believe [Isabella]106-isabella is the handsomest . "[102-mrs. thorpe]

[The Miss Thorpes]107-the thorpes were introduced ; and [Miss Morland]90-miss morland , who had been for a short time forgotten , was introduced likewise . The name seemed to strike [them]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her all ; and , after speaking to [her]102-mrs. thorpe with great civility , [the eldest young lady]423-the eldest young lady observed aloud to [the rest]327-the rest , " How excessively like [[her]423-the eldest young lady brother]2221-her brother [Miss Morland]90-miss morland is ! "[423-the eldest young lady]

" The very picture of [him]2221-her brother indeed ! "[425-the mother] cried [the mother]425-the mother and " [I]425-the mother should have known [her]90-miss morland anywhere for [[his]2221-her brother sister]2222-his sister ! "[425-the mother] was repeated by [them]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her all , two or three times over . For a moment [Catherine]77-catherine was surprised ; but [Mrs. Thorpe]102-mrs. thorpe and [[her]102-mrs. thorpe daughters]207-her daughters had scarcely begun the history of [their]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her acquaintance with [Mr. James Morland]108-james , before [she]77-catherine remembered that [[her]77-catherine eldest brother]427-her eldest brother had lately formed an intimacy with [a young man of [[his]427-her eldest brother own college]429-his own college , of the name of [Thorpe]102-mrs. thorpe]428-a young man of his own college , of the name of thorpe ; and that [he]427-her eldest brother had spent the last week of the Christmas vacation with [[his]427-her eldest brother family]430-his family , near [London]12-london .

The whole being explained , many obliging things were said by [the Miss Thorpes]107-the thorpes of [their]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her wish of being better acquainted with [her]102-mrs. thorpe ; of being considered as [already friends]431-already friends , through the friendship of [[their]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her brothers]432-their brothers , etc . , which [Catherine]77-catherine heard with pleasure , and answered with all the pretty expressions [she]77-catherine could command ; and , as the first proof of amity , [she]77-catherine was soon invited to accept an arm of [the eldest Miss Thorpe]433-the eldest miss thorpe , and take a turn with [her]433-the eldest miss thorpe about [the room]308-the room . [Catherine]77-catherine was delighted with this extension of [her]77-catherine Bath acquaintance , and almost forgot [Mr. Tilney]98-henry while [she]77-catherine talked to [Miss Thorpe]101-miss thorpe . Friendship is certainly the finest balm for the pangs of disappointed love .

[Their]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her conversation turned upon those subjects , of which the free discussion has generally much to do in perfecting a sudden intimacy between [two young ladies]435-two young ladies : such as dress , balls , flirtations , and quizzes . [Miss Thorpe]101-miss thorpe , however , being four years older than [Miss Morland]90-miss morland , and at least four years better informed , had a very decided advantage in discussing such points ; [she]101-miss thorpe could compare the balls of [Bath]5-bath with those of [Tunbridge]13-tunbridge , its fashions with the fashions of [London]12-london ; could rectify the opinions of [[her]101-miss thorpe new friend]436-her new friend in many articles of tasteful attire ; could discover a flirtation between [any gentleman]437-any gentleman and [lady who only smiled on each other]438-lady who only smiled on each other ; and point out a quiz through the thickness of [a crowd]439-a crowd . These powers received due admiration from [Catherine]77-catherine , to whom [they]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her were entirely new ; and the respect which [they]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her naturally inspired might have been too great for familiarity , had not the easy gaiety of [Miss Thorpe]101-miss thorpe s manners , and [her]101-miss thorpe frequent expressions of delight on this acquaintance with [her]101-miss thorpe , softened down every feeling of awe , and left nothing but tender affection . [Their]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her increasing attachment was not to be satisfied with half a dozen turns in [the pump - room]364-the pump - room , but required , when [they]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her all quitted [it]441-it together , that [Miss Thorpe]101-miss thorpe should accompany [Miss Morland]90-miss morland to the very door of [[Mr. Allen]89-mr. allen s house]442-mr. allen s house ; and that [they]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her should there part with a most affectionate and lengthened shake of hands , after learning , to [their]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her mutual relief , that [they]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her should see [each other]338-each other across [the theatre]2151-the theatre at night , and say [their]422-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her prayers in [the same chapel]445-the same chapel the next morning . [Catherine]77-catherine then ran directly [upstairs]446-upstairs , and watched [Miss Thorpe]101-miss thorpe s progress down [the street]447-the street from [the drawing - room]448-the drawing - room window ; admired the graceful spirit of [her]101-miss thorpe walk , the fashionable air of [her]101-miss thorpe figure and dress ; and felt grateful , as well [she]77-catherine might , for the chance which had procured [her]77-catherine such [a friend]449-a friend .

[Mrs. Thorpe]102-mrs. thorpe was [a widow]450-a widow , and [not a very rich one]451-not a very rich one ; [she]102-mrs. thorpe was [a good - humoured , well - meaning woman]452-a good - humoured , well - meaning woman , and [a very indulgent mother]453-a very indulgent mother . [[Her]102-mrs. thorpe eldest daughter]454-her eldest daughter had great personal beauty , and [the younger ones]455-the younger ones , by pretending to be as handsome as [[their]455-the younger ones sister]456-their sister , imitating [her]101-miss thorpe air , and dressing in the same style , did very well .

This brief account of [the family]457-the family is intended to supersede the necessity of a long and minute detail from [Mrs. Thorpe]102-mrs. thorpe [herself]102-mrs. thorpe , of [her]102-mrs. thorpe past adventures and sufferings , which might otherwise be expected to occupy the three or four following chapters ; in which the worthlessness of [lords and attorneys]458-lords and attorneys might be set forth , and conversations , which had passed twenty years before , be minutely repeated .

CHAPTER 5

[Catherine]77-catherine was not so much engaged at [the theatre]2151-the theatre that evening , in returning the nods and smiles of [Miss Thorpe]101-miss thorpe , though [they]460-they certainly claimed much of [her]77-catherine leisure , as to forget to look with an inquiring eye for [Mr. Tilney]98-henry in every box which [her]77-catherine eye could reach ; but [she]77-catherine looked in vain . [Mr. Tilney]98-henry was no fonder of the play than [the pump - room]364-the pump - room . [She]77-catherine hoped to be more fortunate the next day ; and when [her]77-catherine wishes for fine weather were answered by seeing a beautiful morning , [she]77-catherine hardly felt a doubt of it ; for a fine Sunday in [Bath]5-bath empties [every house of [its]364-the pump - room inhabitants]462-every house of its inhabitants , and all [the world]197-the world appears on such an occasion to walk about and tell [their]460-they acquaintance what a charming day it is .

As soon as divine service was over , [the Thorpes]107-the thorpes and [Allens]109-the allens eagerly joined [each other]338-each other ; and after staying long enough in [the pump - room]364-the pump - room to discover that [the crowd was insupportable , and that there was not a genteel face to be seen]466-the crowd was insupportable , and that there was not a genteel face to be seen , which [everybody]326-everybody discovers every Sunday throughout the season , [they]460-they hastened away to [the Crescent]14-the crescent , to breathe the fresh air of better company . Here [Catherine]77-catherine and [Isabella]106-isabella , arm in arm , again tasted the sweets of friendship in an unreserved conversation ; [they]460-they talked much , and with much enjoyment ; but again was [Catherine]77-catherine disappointed in [her]77-catherine hope of reseeing [[her]77-catherine partner]393-her partner . [He]393-her partner was nowhere to be met with ; every search for [him]393-her partner was equally unsuccessful , in [morning lounges]469-morning lounges or evening assemblies ; neither at [the Upper nor Lower Rooms]470-the upper nor lower rooms , at dressed or undressed balls , was [he]393-her partner perceivable ; nor among [the walkers]471-the walkers , [the horsemen]472-the horsemen , or [the curricle - drivers of the morning]473-the curricle - drivers of the morning . [His]393-her partner name was not in the pump - room book , and curiosity could do no more . [He]393-her partner must be gone from [Bath]5-bath . Yet [he]393-her partner had not mentioned that [his]393-her partner stay would be so short ! This sort of mysteriousness , which is always so becoming in [a hero]248-a hero , threw a fresh grace in [Catherine]77-catherine s imagination around [his]393-her partner person and manners , and increased [her]77-catherine anxiety to know more of [him]393-her partner . From [the Thorpes]107-the thorpes [she]77-catherine could learn nothing , for [they]475-they had been only two days in [Bath]2155-bath before [they]475-they met with [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen . It was a subject , however , in which [she]77-catherine often indulged with [[her]77-catherine fair friend]477-her fair friend , from whom [she]77-catherine received every possible encouragement to continue to think of [him]393-her partner ; and [his]393-her partner impression on [her]77-catherine fancy was not suffered therefore to weaken . [Isabella]106-isabella was very sure that [he]393-her partner must be [a charming young man]478-a charming young man , and was equally sure that [he]393-her partner must have been delighted with [[her]77-catherine dear]479-her dear [Catherine]77-catherine , and would therefore shortly return . [She]77-catherine liked [him]393-her partner the better for being [a clergyman]191-a clergyman , " for [she]77-catherine must confess [herself]77-catherine very partial to the profession "[77-catherine] ; and something like a sigh escaped [her]77-catherine as [she]77-catherine said it . Perhaps [Catherine]77-catherine was wrong in not demanding the cause of that gentle emotion but [she]77-catherine was not experienced enough in the finesse of love , or the duties of friendship , to know when delicate raillery was properly called for , or when a confidence should be forced .

[Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen was now quite happy quite satisfied with [Bath]2155-bath . [She]91-mrs. allen had found some acquaintance , had been so lucky too as to find in [them]482-them [the family of [a most worthy old friend]484-a most worthy old friend]483-the family of a most worthy old friend ; and , as the completion of good fortune , had found [these friends]485-these friends by no means so expensively dressed as [herself]91-mrs. allen . [Her]91-mrs. allen daily expressions were no longer , " [I]486-i wish [we]2223-we had some acquaintance in [Bath]5-bath ! "[486-i] [They]486-i were changed into , " How glad [I]91-mrs. allen am [we]2223-we have met with [Mrs. Thorpe]102-mrs. thorpe ! "[91-mrs. allen] and [she]91-mrs. allen was as eager in promoting the intercourse of [the two families]487-the two families , as [[her]91-mrs. allen young charge]488-her young charge and [Isabella]106-isabella [themselves]487-the two families could be ; never satisfied with the day unless [she]91-mrs. allen spent the chief of it by the side of [Mrs. Thorpe]102-mrs. thorpe , in what [they]487-the two families called conversation , but in which there was scarcely ever any exchange of opinion , and not often any resemblance of subject , for [Mrs. Thorpe]102-mrs. thorpe talked chiefly of [[her]102-mrs. thorpe children]221-her children , and [Mrs. Allen]91-mrs. allen of [her]102-mrs. thorpe gowns .

The progress of the friendship between [Catherine]77-catherine and [Isabella]106-isabella was quick as its beginning had been warm , and [they]487-the two families passed so rapidly through every gradation of increasing tenderness that there was shortly no fresh proof of it to be given to [[their]487-the two families friends]490-their friends or [themselves]487-the two families . [They]487-the two families called [each other]338-each other by [their]487-the two families Christian name , were always arm in arm when [they]487-the two families walked , pinned up [each other]338-each other s train for the dance , and were not to be divided in the set ; and if a rainy morning deprived [them]487-the two families of other enjoyments , [they]487-the two families were still resolute in meeting in defiance of wet and dirt , and shut [themselves]487-the two families up , to read novels together . Yes , novels ; for [I]0-i will not adopt that ungenerous and impolitic custom so common with [novel - writers]493-novel - writers , of degrading by [their]493-novel - writers contemptuous censure the very performances , to the number of which [they]493-novel - writers are [themselves]493-novel - writers adding joining with [[their]493-novel - writers greatest enemies]494-their greatest enemies in bestowing the harshest epithets on such works , and scarcely ever permitting [them]493-novel - writers to be read by [[their]487-the two families own heroine]495-their own heroine , who , if [she]495-their own heroine accidentally take up a novel , is sure to turn over its insipid pages with disgust . Alas ! If [the heroine of one novel]496-the heroine of one novel be not patronized by [the heroine of another]497-the heroine of another , from whom can [she]495-their own heroine expect protection and regard ? [I]0-i can not approve of it . Let [us]498-our leave it to [the reviewers]499-the reviewers to abuse such effusions of fancy at [their]499-the reviewers leisure , and over every new novel to talk in threadbare strains of the trash with which the press now groans . Let [us]498-our not desert [one another]500-one another ; [we]498-our are [an injured body]501-an injured body . Although [our]498-our productions have afforded more extensive and unaffected pleasure than those of any other literary corporation in [the world]197-the world , no species of composition has been so much decried . From pride , ignorance , or fashion , [[our]498-our foes]503-our foes are almost as many as [[our]498-our readers]504-our readers . And while the abilities of the nine - hundredth abridger of the History of [England]2-england , or of [the man who collects and publishes in a volume some dozen lines of Milton , Pope]505-the man who collects and publishes in a volume some dozen lines of milton , pope , and Prior , with a paper from [the Spectator]506-the spectator , and a chapter from Sterne , are eulogized by a thousand pens there seems almost a general wish of decrying the capacity and undervaluing the labour of [the novelist]507-the novelist , and of slighting the performances which have only genius , wit , and taste to recommend them . " [I]508-the young lady am [no novel - reader]2224-no novel - reader [I]508-the young lady seldom look into novels Do not imagine that _ [I]508-the young lady _ often read novels It is really very well for a novel . "[508-the young lady] Such is the common ca nt . " And what are [you]508-the young lady reading , [Miss]2225-miss ? "[508-the young lady] " Oh ! It is only a novel ! "[508-the young lady] replies [the young lady]508-the young lady , while [she]508-the young lady lays down [her]508-the young lady book with affected indifference , or momentary shame . " It is only [Cecilia]110-cecilia , or [Camilla]111-camilla , or [Belinda]112-belinda "[508-the young lady] ; or , in short , only some work in which the greatest powers of the mind are displayed , in which the most thorough knowledge of human nature , the happiest delineation of its varieties , the liveliest effusions of wit and humour , are conveyed to [the world]197-the world in the best - chosen language . Now , had [the same young lady been engaged with a volume of the Spectator]510-the same young lady been engaged with a volume of the spectator , instead of such a work , how proudly would [she]508-the young lady have produced the book , and told its name ; though the chances must be against [her]508-the young lady being occupied by any part of that voluminous publication , of which either the matter or manner would not disgust [a young person of taste]511-a young person of taste : the substance of its papers so often consisting in the statement of improbable circumstances , unnatural characters , and topics of conversation which no longer concern [anyone living]512-anyone living ; and [their]513-their language , too , frequently so coarse as to give no very favourable idea of the age that could endure it .

CHAPTER 6

The following conversation , which took place between [the two friends]514-the two friends in [the pump - room]364-the pump - room one morning , after [an acquaintance of eight or nine days]516-an acquaintance of eight or nine days , is given as a specimen of [their]514-the two friends very warm attachment , and of the delicacy , discretion , originality of thought , and literary taste which marked the reasonableness of that attachment .

[They]514-the two friends met by appointment ; and as [Isabella]106-isabella had arrived nearly five minutes before [[her]106-isabella friend]313-her friend , [her]106-isabella first address naturally was , " [[My]106-isabella dearest]2226-my dearest creature , what can have made [you]2226-my dearest so late ? [I]106-isabella have been waiting for [you]2226-my dearest at least this age ! "[106-isabella]

" Have [you]2226-my dearest , indeed ! [I]106-isabella am very sorry for it ; but really [I]106-isabella thought [I]106-isabella was in very good time . It is but just one . [I]106-isabella hope [you]2226-my dearest have not been [here]2128-here long ? "[106-isabella]

" Oh ! These ten ages at least . [I]106-isabella am sure [I]106-isabella have been [here]2128-here this half hour . But now , let [us]514-the two friends go and sit down at the other end of [the room]308-the room , and enjoy [ourselves]514-the two friends . [I]106-isabella have an hundred things to say to [you]2226-my dearest . In the first place , [I]106-isabella was so afraid it would rain this morning , just as [I]106-isabella wanted to set off ; it looked very showery , and that would have thrown [me]106-isabella into agonies ! Do [you]2226-my dearest know , [I]106-isabella saw the prettiest hat [you]2226-my dearest can imagine , in [a shop window in [Milsom Street]15-milsom street]2230-a shop window in milsom street just now very like [yours]2226-my dearest , only with coquelicot ribbons instead of green ; [I]106-isabella quite longed for it . But , [[my]106-isabella dearest]2226-my dearest [Catherine]77-catherine , what have [you]2226-my dearest been doing with [yourself]2226-my dearest all this morning ? Have [you]2226-my dearest gone on with [Udolpho]113-udolpho ? "[106-isabella]

" Yes , [I]106-isabella have been reading it ever since [I]106-isabella woke ; and [I]106-isabella am got to the black veil . "[106-isabella]

" Are [you]2226-my dearest , indeed ? How delightful ! Oh ! [I]106-isabella would not tell [you]2226-my dearest what is behind the black veil for [the world]197-the world ! Are not [you]2226-my dearest wild to know ? "[106-isabella]

" Oh ! Yes , quite ; what can it be ? But do not tell [me]106-isabella [I]106-isabella would not be told upon any account . [I]106-isabella know it must be a skeleton , [I]106-isabella am sure it is [Laurentina]114-laurentina s skeleton . Oh ! [I]106-isabella am delighted with the book ! [I]106-isabella should like to spend [my]106-isabella whole life in reading it . [I]106-isabella assure [you]2226-my dearest , if it had not been to meet [you]2226-my dearest , [I]106-isabella would not have come away from it for all [the world]197-the world . "[106-isabella]

" [Dear creature]2234-dear creature ! How much [I]106-isabella am obliged to [you]2226-my dearest ; and when [you]2226-my dearest have finished [Udolpho]113-udolpho , [we]2235-we will read the Italian together ; and [I]106-isabella have made out a list of ten or twelve more of the same kind for [you]2226-my dearest . "[106-isabella]

" Have [you]2226-my dearest , indeed ! How glad [I]106-isabella am ! What are [they]2236-they all ? "[106-isabella]

" [I]106-isabella will read [you]2226-my dearest [their]2236-they names directly ; here they are , in [my]106-isabella pocketbook . [Castle of [Wolfenbach]16-wolfenbach]2237-castle of wolfenbach , [Clermont]17-clermont , Mysterious Warnings , [Necromancer of [the Black Forest]19-the black forest]18-necromancer of the black forest , [Midnight Bell]20-midnight bell , [Orphan of [the Rhine]22-the rhine]21-orphan of the rhine , and Horrid Mysteries . Those will last [us]2235-we some time . "[106-isabella]

" Yes , pretty well ; but are [they]2236-they all horrid , are [you]2226-my dearest sure [they]2236-they are all horrid ? "[106-isabella]

" Yes , quite sure ; for [a particular friend of mine]2238-a particular friend of mine , [a [Miss Andrews]115-miss andrews , [a sweet girl]2240-a sweet girl , one of the sweetest creatures in [the world]197-the world]2239-a miss andrews , a sweet girl , one of the sweetest creatures in the world , has read every one of [them]2236-they . [I]106-isabella wish [you]2226-my dearest knew [Miss Andrews]115-miss andrews , [you]2226-my dearest would be delighted with [her]115-miss andrews . [She]115-miss andrews is netting [herself]115-miss andrews the sweetest cloak [you]2226-my dearest can conceive . [I]106-isabella think [her]115-miss andrews as beautiful as [an angel]2242-an angel , and [I]106-isabella am so vexed with [the men]2243-the men for not admiring [her]115-miss andrews ! [I]106-isabella scold [them]2243-the men all amazingly about it . "[106-isabella]

" Scold [them]2243-the men ! Do [you]106-isabella scold [them]2243-the men for not admiring [her]115-miss andrews ? "[106-isabella]

" Yes , that [I]106-isabella do . There is nothing [I]106-isabella would not do for [those who are really [[my]106-isabella friends]2245-my friends]2244-those who are really my friends . [I]106-isabella have no notion of loving [people]328-people by halves ; it is not [my]106-isabella nature . [My]106-isabella attachments are always excessively strong . [I]106-isabella told [Captain Hunt]116-captain hunt at one of [[our]2247-our assemblies]2248-our assemblies this winter that if [he]116-captain hunt was to tease [me]106-isabella all night , [I]106-isabella would not dance with [him]116-captain hunt , unless [he]116-captain hunt would allow [Miss Andrews]115-miss andrews to be as beautiful as [an angel]2242-an angel . [The men]2243-the men think [us]2247-our incapable of real friendship , [you]2251-you know , and [I]106-isabella am determined to show [them]2243-the men the difference . Now , if [I]106-isabella were to hear [anybody]198-anybody speak slightingly of [you]2251-you , [I]106-isabella should fire up in a moment : but that is not at all likely , for _ [you]2251-you _ are just the kind of girl to be a great favourite with [the men]2243-the men . "[106-isabella]

" Oh , dear ! "[77-catherine] cried [Catherine]77-catherine , colouring . " How can [you]77-catherine say so ? "[77-catherine]

" [I]77-catherine know [you]2251-you very well ; [you]2251-you have so much animation , which is exactly what [Miss Andrews]115-miss andrews wants , for [I]77-catherine must confess there is something amazingly insipid about [her]115-miss andrews . Oh ! [I]77-catherine must tell [you]2251-you , that just after [we]2254-we parted yesterday , [I]77-catherine saw [a young man]2255-a young man looking at [you]2251-you so earnestly [I]77-catherine am sure [he]2255-a young man is in love with [you]2251-you . "[77-catherine] [Catherine]77-catherine coloured , and disclaimed again . [Isabella]106-isabella laughed . " It is very true , upon [my]106-isabella honour , but [I]106-isabella see how it is ; [you]2251-you are indifferent to [everybody]326-everybody s admiration , except that of [one gentleman]2257-one gentleman , who shall be nameless . Nay , [I]106-isabella can not blame [you]2251-you "[106-isabella] speaking more seriously " [your]2251-you feelings are easily understood . Where the heart is really attached , [I]106-isabella know very well how little one can be pleased with the attention of [anybody else]2258-anybody else . Everything is so insipid , so uninteresting , that does not relate to [the beloved object]2259-the beloved object ! [I]106-isabella can perfectly comprehend [your]2251-you feelings . "[106-isabella]

" But [you]2251-you should not persuade [me]106-isabella that [I]106-isabella think so very much about [Mr. Tilney]98-henry , for perhaps [I]106-isabella may never see [him]98-henry again . "[106-isabella]

" Not see [him]98-henry again ! [[My]106-isabella dearest]2226-my dearest creature , do not talk of it . [I]106-isabella am sure [you]2251-you would be miserable if [you]2251-you thought so ! "[106-isabella]

" No , indeed , [I]106-isabella should not . [I]106-isabella do not pretend to say that [I]106-isabella was not very much pleased with [him]98-henry ; but while [I]106-isabella have [Udolpho]113-udolpho to read , [I]106-isabella feel as if [nobody]2139-nobody could make [me]106-isabella miserable . Oh ! The dreadful black veil ! [[My]106-isabella dear]2124-my dear [Isabella]106-isabella , [I]106-isabella am sure there must be [Laurentina]114-laurentina s skeleton behind it . "[106-isabella]

" It is so odd to [me]106-isabella , that [you]2251-you should never have read [Udolpho]113-udolpho before ; but [I]106-isabella suppose [Mrs. Morland]82-mrs. morland objects to novels . "[106-isabella]

" No , [she]82-mrs. morland does not . [She]82-mrs. morland very often reads [Sir Charles Grandison]117-sir charles grandison [herself]82-mrs. morland ; but new books do not fall in [our]2263-our way . "[106-isabella]

" [Sir Charles Grandison]117-sir charles grandison ! That is an amazing horrid book , is it not ? [I]106-isabella remember [Miss Andrews]115-miss andrews could not get through the first volume . "[106-isabella]

" It is not like [Udolpho]113-udolpho at all ; but yet [I]106-isabella think it is very entertaining . "[106-isabella]

" Do [you]2251-you indeed ! [You]2251-you surprise [me]106-isabella ; [I]106-isabella thought it had not been readable . " But it does not signify if [they]2243-the men do , "[77-catherine] said [Catherine]77-catherine , very innocently .

" Signify ! Oh , heavens ! [I]106-isabella make it a rule never to mind what [they]2243-the men say . "[106-isabella]

" Are [they]2243-the men ? Well , [I]106-isabella never observed _ that _ . [They]2243-the men always behave very well to [me]106-isabella . "[106-isabella]

" Oh ! [They]2243-the men give [themselves]2243-the men such airs . [They]2243-the men are [the most conceited creatures in [the world]197-the world]2266-the most conceited creatures in the world , and think [themselves]2243-the men of so much importance ! By the by , though [I]106-isabella have thought of it a hundred times , [I]106-isabella have always forgot to ask [you]77-catherine what is [your]77-catherine favourite complexion in [a man]2268-a man . " [I]106-isabella hardly know . [I]106-isabella never much thought about it . Something between both , [I]106-isabella think . Brown not fair , and and not very dark . "[106-isabella]

" Very well , [Catherine]77-catherine . That is exactly [he]2268-a man . [I]106-isabella have not forgot [your]77-catherine description of [Mr. Tilney]98-henry a brown skin , with dark eyes , and rather dark hair . Well , [my]106-isabella taste is different .
